citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
-The zebra's hooves are overgrown and cracked, all four feet are affected. Overgrown hooves may cause lameness and
pain and lead to other foot and leg problems. The zebra's hooves must be trimmed, and also maintained as needed.
-Two turkeys were observed with swollen footpads and limping. The licensee stated that the animals are not receiving any
medical treatment for their condition. Abnormal conditions of the feet could cause pain and discomfort to the animals. The
turkeys must seek veterinary care to devise a treatment.
The facility shall establish and maintain an adequate program of veterinary care that includes appropriate methods to
diagnose and control disease, including adequate hoof/foot care and management of orthopedic diseases and prevention
of injuries. Correct by March 4, 2024

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, an updated program of veterinary care, and environmental enhancement
program for non-human primates and birds, were still not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required
by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and
evaluate animal welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the
regulations are available for USDA APHIS officials to examine.

The facility, which houses primates and other exotic animals in outdoor enclosures, still does not have an adequate
perimeter fence. Most of the premises is surrounded by a perimeter fence that is less than 6 feet tall and covered in
overgrown vegetation. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A
perimeter fence also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by
installing a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, and to act as a
secondary containment system for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the
APHIS Administrator.

The enclosure housing three lemurs and the one housing a single lemur do not have public barriers. The inspector
observed members of the public sticking their fingers in the cage with the single housed lemur. Not providing adequate
barriers between the public and NHPs puts both the public and the NHPs at risk of injury. Fixed public exhibits housing
nonhuman primates must have a barrier between the primary enclosure and the public at any time the public is present, in
order to restrict physical contact between the public and the nonhuman primates. Correct by March 12, 2024.

Chickens and guinea fowl are still housed in a wire outdoor enclosure which contain multiple sharp points. The sharp
points are found around areas that the birds frequent such as the water and food receptacles.
Enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the birds within. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp edges that could injure the birds. The primary enclosures must
also be kept in good repair.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
-The zebra's hooves are overgrown and cracked, all four feet are affected. Overgrown hooves may cause lameness and 
pain and lead to other foot and leg problems. The zebra's hooves must be trimmed, and also maintained as needed.  
-Two turkeys were observed with swollen footpads and limping. The licensee stated that the animals are not receiving any 
medical treatment for their condition. Abnormal conditions of the feet could cause pain and discomfort to the animals. The 
turkeys must seek veterinary care to devise a treatment.  
 
The facility shall establish and maintain an adequate program of veterinary care that includes appropriate methods to 
diagnose and control disease, including adequate hoof/foot care and management of orthopedic diseases and prevention 
of injuries. Correct by March 4, 2024 
2.126(a)(2)  Repeat
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, an updated program of veterinary care, and environmental enhancement 
program for non-human primates and birds, were still not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required 
by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and 
evaluate animal welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the 
regulations are available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. 
3.78(d)  Repeat
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The facility, which houses primates and other exotic animals in outdoor enclosures, still does not have an adequate 
perimeter fence. Most of the premises is surrounded by a perimeter fence that is less than 6 feet tall and covered in 
overgrown vegetation. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A 
perimeter fence also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by 
installing a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, and to act as a 
secondary containment system for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the 
APHIS Administrator.

3.78(e) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The enclosure housing three lemurs and the one housing a single lemur do not have public barriers. The inspector 
observed members of the public sticking their fingers in the cage with the single housed lemur. Not providing adequate 
barriers between the public and NHPs puts both the public and the NHPs at risk of injury. Fixed public exhibits housing 
nonhuman primates must have a barrier between the primary enclosure and the public at any time the public is present, in 
order to restrict physical contact between the public and the nonhuman primates. Correct by March 12, 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(i)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
Chickens and guinea fowl are still housed in a wire outdoor enclosure which contain multiple sharp points. The sharp 
points are found around areas that the birds frequent such as the water and food receptacles. 
 
Enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the birds within. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be 
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp edges that could injure the birds. The primary enclosures must 
also be kept in good repair. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
